Manganese oxides were received extensive attention on account of its low cost, variable valence state and excellent redox properties. Herein, we successfully prepared various Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts to further improve the catalytic activity of MnO2 on propane. Physicochemical characterization results displayed that with the increase of Fe doping amounts, the crystalline phase of MnO2 gradually changed from α-MnO2 and β-MnO2 to Fe2O3, the particle size of catalysts decreased and the specific surface area increased. However, increasing the content of Fe could not monotonically enhance the catalytic performance of catalysts on propane. When the molar ratio of Fe/Mn was 0.25, the largest amount of Mn4+ species and lattice oxygen species were exposed on the surface of Mn8Fe2, and showed the best low temperature reducibility, which was ascribed to the synergistic effect between Mn and Fe was enhanced. It presented optimal catalytic activity for propane oxidation with temperature of propane conversion at 90% (T90) as low as 279 °C under 0.1% propane and 5% O2. This work provided a new way to design and synthesize efficient non-noble metal catalysts for the elimination of propane, which had certain application value. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Manganese dioxide Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts Synergistic effect Propane oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Petrochemical, road transportation, and other industries emit large amounts of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) into the atmosphere [1–3]. VOCs encompass a variety of compounds, resulting in a complex composition. Apart from being inherently carcinogenic and causing irritation and other health issues, they also contribute to the generation of ozone and act as precursors to photochemical haze, posing a serious threat to the natural environment [4,5]. Various methods for VOCs removal are available, including adsorption, biodegradation, direct combustion, and catalytic combustion [6–8]. Among these, catalytic combustion stands out due to its advantages of low light-off temperature and high removal efficiency, making it a promising approach to enhance propane combustion efficiency [9]. As a result, research on propane catalytic combustion holds urgent practical value. Catalysts containing precious metals such as Pt, Ru, Pd, Au, and others have been extensively utilized in VOCs catalytic combustion, demonstrating excellent activity in eliminating VOCs at low temperatures [10–12]. While noble metal catalysts have exhibited remarkable efficiency in catalytic combustion, their widespread application has been restricted due to resource scarcity, high cost, susceptibility to poisoning, and inactivation during the catalytic reaction process [13]. In recent years, there has been a surge in research on alternative materials for precious metal catalysts. Transition metal catalysts have garnered significant attention as potential alternatives. They possess a wide range of sources, variable valence states, low cost, excellent stability, and considerable catalytic activity for VOCs removal, making them viable substitutes for precious metal catalysts [14]. Among these alternatives, metal oxides like MnOx, NiOx, CoOx, CeOx, and CuOx have been extensively studied. They have been proven to offer high activity and cost-effectiveness, thereby attracting widespread attention from researchers in the field of VOCs catalytic combustion [15–19]. Manganese oxide, as a prevalent type of transition metal oxide, has garnered extensive attention owing to its affordability, variable valence, and potent redox ability, establishing it as an efficient catalyst for VOCs treatment [20–22]. Lu et al. utilized a solvent-thermal-reduction approach to create a porous nanosheet catalyst of MnO2 (referred to as MnO2-PS) enriched with oxygen vacancies. This unique structure of MnO2-PS enhanced its ability to undergo redox reactions and activate oxygen, resulting in a greater generation of reactive oxygen species. Additionally, thanked to its porous nanosheet architecture, the MnO2-PS catalyst offered a substantial surface area that allowed for more active sites, thereby promoting the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules [23]. Feng et al. designed a straightforward two-step synthesis method to create a secondary sphere structured δ-type MnO2 (referred to as D-MnO2). Compared to other spherical MnO2 samples, D-MnO2 demonstrated remarkable enhancements in propane oxidation activity. This was attributed to the high specific surface area and there was a significant content of Mn4+ species and excellent oxygen mobility on the surface of the catalyst [24]. Li et al. utilized obsolete ternary Li ion batteries as starting materials to create a new catalyst for propane oxidation. The defect-enhanced CoMnNiOx catalyst exhibited a remarkably low T90 value. The enhanced catalytic activity of the CoMnNiOx catalyst was attributed to the increased presence of oxygen vacancy defects, which resulted from the delithiation and dealumination processes during alkaline etching [25]. Tan et al. utilized imidazolium-based ionic liquids to prepare various MnO2 structures and morphology. By altering the alkyl chain length of the ionic liquids influenced surface tension and steric hindrance, thus impacting the growth of MnO2. It led to a change in the specific surface area and surface active oxygen of catalysts, and affected the active sites that could be used for catalytic reactions, thereby influencing the catalytic performance of the catalysts [26]. In this paper, we modified MnO2 by introducing varying amounts of Fe through an ionic liquid [EMIM-BF4] assisted hydrothermal reaction, thereby synthesizing Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts with varying morphology. The effects of different Fe doping levels on the structural and chemical properties of the MnO2 catalysts were investigated through various characterization experiments. Furthermore, catalytic performance tests were conducted using propane to evaluate the catalytic activity of the Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts with varying molar ratios of Fe/M (M=Mn+Fe), were synthesized using KMnO4 (Aladdin, AR) and Fe(NO3)·9H2O (Aladdin, AR) as starting materials with an ionic liquid as auxiliary raw materials assisted hydrothermal method, as we reported (the purity of all reagents was AR) [27]. Synthesis of Fe-MnO2 catalysts as follows: Firstly, KMnO4 and Fe(NO3)·9H2O (with the molar ratios of Fe/M of 0.1, 0.15, 0.2 and 0.25, respectively) were dissolved in 80 mL of hyperpure water, followed by adding to the identical molar ratio (1:8) of [EMIM-BF4]:M and stirred at indoor temperature for 20 min. Subsequently, the stirred solution was transferred to a hydrothermal kettle and allowed to sit at 160 °C for 24 h. After cooling, the precipitate was washed thoroughly after centrifugation for several times. Eventually, the dried samples were ground and calcined at 500 °C. The products with the molar ratio of Fe/M of 0.1, 0.15, 0.2 and 0.25 were named as Mn9Fe1, Mn8.5Fe1.5, Mn8Fe2 and Mn7.5Fe2.5 respectively. The schematic illustration of [EMIM-BF4] assisted preparation of Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts was presented in Scheme 1 . 2.2 Characterization techniques X-ray diffraction (XRD) data patterns of the as-prepared samples were carried out on the Rigaku Smartlab 9 kW X-ray diffractometer. The operating voltage was 40 kV and tube current was 100 mA. 2θ scans was 10∼80° and the rate was 10°/min. N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were conducted on the BELSORP MINI at −196 °C. Before the determination, the samples were pretreated in vacuum at a temperature of 200 °C and a time of 3.5 h. The morphology of the catalysts was observed using a HITA­ CHI S4800. The catalysts were underwent pretreatment in a vacuum with tube voltage and current of 6 kV and 9 μA, respectively. FEI Tecnai G2 F30 was used to analyze the microstructure of the samples. The elements and valence states on the surface of samples were examined utilizing a PHI-5000 Versa Probe X-ray spectrometer. The radiation source was selected to be Kα (hv=1486.6 eV) monochromatic rays of Al target, and the tube voltage was 12 kV. In order to eliminate charge effects, the collected XPS data was standardized utilizing the C 1 s peak (284.6 eV), and the spectrogram was analyzed using XPSPEAK41 software for fitting processing. The H2-temperatured-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was measured by Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. The sample was pressed and ground by the tablet press and screened before testing. 30 mg samples (40∼60 meshs) were placed in U-shaped tubes and pre-treated at 200 °C in high purity Ar atmosphere for 2 h, then reduced to room temperature. The temperature was raised to 800 °C in 10% H2/90% Ar atmosphere, and the signal changes of exhaust gas were detected by TCD. 50 mg (40∼60 meshs) samples were also weighed in AutoChem II 2920 automatic chemisorption apparatus (Micromeritics) for O2-temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD). Before testing, the catalysts were first treated with hyperpure helium at 200 °C. Then brought dropped to indoor temperature, and then remained at 80 °C for 2 h in a 3% O2/He atmosphere. Lately hyperpure helium was injected to eliminate redundant O2 on the surface of the samples. Finally, the temperature rose to 900 °C in helium atmosphere. Raman spectra were recorded on a UK-Renishaw-Renishaw inVia with 532-nm laser excitation. The scanning range was set at 100–1000 cm−1. In-situ DRIFTs was recorded on a German-Bruker-VERTEX 80v. In-situ DRIFTs spectra of propane oxidation (1000 ppm of C3H8+5vol% O2/N2, 50 mL/min) of Mn8Fe2 were measured as the temperature-dependent at 50–300 °C. The scanning range was set at 1000–4000 cm−1. 2.3 Catalytic performance tests The 0.1 g catalyst was mixed with 0.3 g quartz sand and put it in the middle of a quartz, and both ends were secured with quartz cotton. The thermocouple was inserted into the catalyst bed, and then the quartz tube was fixed in the heating furnace. Prior to the performance evaluation, it was pretreated for 30 min at 120 °C in N2 atmosphere, and then switched to reactive gas mixture (0.1% C3H8, 5% O2/N2, equilibrium), the total flow velocity was 50 mL/min, equaled to the space velocity of 30,000 mL/(g·h). After the feed gas was evenly mixed, the heating switch was started and the temperature was programmed to 450 °C. At the same time, the outlet gas concentration was detected by flue gas analyzer (Infralyt 50). When the reaction was over, terminate the data acquisition software, turn off the heating program, and cut off the feed gas. In this paper, we evaluated the catalytic activity of the catalyst by introducing parameters such as T50 and T90, which represent the temperature of 50% and 90% propane conversion, respectively. The propane conversion rate equation was counted as follows: X = C in − C out C in × 100 % Reaction kinetic indexes were estimated in the reactor. In order to overlook the influence of heat transfer and mass, only the portion of the propane conversion below 15% was calculated. The formula of reaction rate r was displayed: r = X × V W c a t Among them, X represented the propane conversion rate, V was the propane conversion rate, and Wcat was the catalyst mass, respectively. The equation for calculating the activation energy of the reaction was as follows: ln r = − E a R T + C 3 Result and discussion 3.1 XRD XRD patterns was utilized to determine the crystal structure of the Mn9Fe1, Mn8.5Fe1.5, Mn8Fe2, and Mn7.5Fe2.5 obtained using [EMIM-BF4] as a assisting agent. The results were shown in Fig. 1 . According to Fig. 1(a), the characteristic peaks of α-MnO2 (PDF# 44–0141) were present at 2θ values of 12.8°, 18.1°, 49.8°, 60.0°, and 69.4° These peaks might have resulted from the decomposition of KMnO4 during the reaction [26,27]. Besides, the main diffraction peaks of all catalysts appeared at 2θ of 28.7°, 37.4°, 46.2°, 56.3° and 72.6°, corresponding to the crystal structure of β-MnO2 (PDF# 42–1317). All catalysts displayed primary peaks at 2θ of 33.1°, 36.5°, 41.5°, 54.4° and 65.8°, which could be attributed to (104), (110), (113), (116) and (125) facets of Fe2O3 (PDF# 33–0664), respectively. The Mn9Fe1 and Mn8.5Fe1.5 were predominantly composed of MnO2 as the crystalline phase, while in the Mn8Fe2 and Mn7.5Fe2.5, the diffraction peaks intensities of β-MnO2 and α-MnO2 gradually weakened or even disappeared, and Fe2O3 became the main crystalline phase. Observation of Fig. 1(b) revealed that with the augment of Fe doping amounts, the characteristic peaks intensities of Fe2O3 were gradually increased, while the peaks corresponding to MnO2 with much lower intensities and broadened width could be seen in XRD patterns of Mn8Fe2 and Mn7.5Fe2.5. The introduction of Fe degraded the crystallinity of MnO2. Additionally, the peak of β-MnO2 in Mn8.5Fe1.5, Mn8Fe2 and Mn7.5Fe2.5 shifted toward lower angle with respect to the peak of β-MnO2 in Mn9Fe1, indicating some Fe3+ ions dissolved into the MnO2 lattice [28,29]. This might be due to the fact that the substitution of Fe3+ ions for the some Mn4+ions in the MnO2 lattice [30]. The radius of Fe3+ was larger than the radius of Mn4+, which might lead to generate lattice expansion and the instability of the local charge when Fe3+ substituted Mn4+ [31]. As a mechanism of charge compensation, the oxygen vacancies would be formed which were adjacent to Fe3+ and Mn3+species. However, the excessive Fe doping resulted in Fe2O3 generation outside of MnO2 lattice, the catalyst structure was more inclined to support Fe2O3 on MnO2 [30]. It was reported that lattice defects accomplished lower crystallinity, more oxygen vacancies and internal atoms could be exposed, thus providing more active sites for catalyzing oxidation reaction and facilitating the generation of more reactive oxygen species [32–34]. 3.2 SEM SEM was used to reflect the morphology and microstructure of the catalysts. According to Fig. 2 , in addition to slender nanorods, the Mn9Fe1 sample contained many irregular polyhedral particles, which had large sizes and were distributed in a concentrated manner. With increasing Fe3+ concentration, the number of nanorods of Mn8.5Fe1.5 enlarged significantly, and the size of the polyhedral particles was reduced by 3–4 times compared with that of Mn9Fe1. Polyhedral particles could not be observed on the surface of Mn8Fe2, the morphology of polyhedral particles was mainly composed of small cotton clusters interwoven between nanorods, with relatively loose structure and abundant pores, which was conducive to adsorbing and activating gas molecules [35]. The morphology of Mn7.5Fe2.5 was similar to that of Mn8Fe2, but its structure was more compact and the cluster phenomenon was obvious. 3.3 TEM TEM tests were conducted to further examine the influence of Fe content on the microstructure of the MnO2 samples. As seen from Fig. 3 , these catalysts displayed that the morphology of the catalysts was consistent with the SEM images. In Mn9Fe1, many irregular polyhedral particles were clustered around a small number of nanorods, while in Mn8.5Fe1.5, only a few irregular polyhedron were distributed across the interlaced nanorods. However, Mn8Fe2 and Mn7.5Fe2.5 were dominantly composed of nanoflower clusters with loose structure. Combined with the N2 adsorption-desorption characterization below, it indicated the doping amounts of Fe had a significant effect on the morphological characteristics of the samples and also changed the pore structure of the samples. Fig. 3(a3) showed the lattice fringes on the surface of Mn9Fe1 were 0.241 nm and 0.266 nm could be assigned to (101) crystal plane of β-MnO2 and (104) crystal plane of Fe2O3, respectively. As displayed in Fig. 3(b3), the lattice stripes on the surface of Mn8.5Fe1.5 were 0.311 nm and 0.169 nm, which were owing to the (110) crystal plane of β-MnO2 and the (116) crystal plane of Fe2O3. From Fig. 3(c3), on the surface of Mn8Fe2, the lattice spacing were 0.250 nm and 0.212 nm, which could be indexed to (110) crystal plane of Fe2O3 and (111) crystal plane of β-MnO2, respectively. In Fig. 3(d3), the lattice distances measured on the surface of Mn7.5Fe2.5 were 0.252 nm and 0.143 nm were consistent with the (110) crystal plane of Fe2O3 and (002) crystal plane of β-MnO2, respectively. The above TEM analysis further confirmed the successful preparation of Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts. 3.4 N2 adsorption-desorption The N2 adsorption-desorption tests were utilized to explore the porous structures of Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts displayed in Fig. 4 . In addition, the specific surface area of the prepared catalysts calculated according to BET equation was displayed in Table 1 . As seen from Fig. 4(a), all catalysts presented IV-type isotherms and H3 hysteresis loop at high relative pressure. The adsorption capacity of samples increased significantly in the range of relative pressure 0.8–1.0, indicating that the catalysts had a mesoporous structure [36,37]. Comparing these samples, it was found that Mn7.5Fe2.5 and Mn8Fe2 exhibited higher adsorption capacity, indicating they had excellent pore structure. As listed in Table 1, Mn9Fe1 presented much smaller specific surface area than other catalysts. However, Mn7.5Fe2.5 exhibited optimal pore volume and the largest specific surface area, which might result from they possessed more defects, as obtained from the above XRD analysis. Besides, based on the SEM analysis results, we speculated that with the number and size of irregular polyhedral particles decreased, the further growth of nanorods intersected and entwined with each other, forming loose clusters similar to cotton, which might be conducive to increasing specific surface area and the formation of porous structure of the catalysts [38]. The BJH pore size distribution was calculated from adsorption-desorption isotherms, and further indicated the pore structure of the all catalysts. Fig. 4(b) was summarized the pore size distribution of all catalysts, with numerous peaks occurring between 2 and 40 nm, which further confirmed the presence of mesoporous structures in the surface of catalysts. The peaks of Mn7.5Fe2.5 and Mn8Fe2 exhibited much higher intensities than other catalysts, which inferred they had more substantial mesoporous structures. These mesoporous could provide more exposed propane oxidation active sites and abundant pore structures for catalytic reactions [39]. 3.5 XPS The surface element valence and content of all catalysts were conducted by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS). Fig. 5 showed the spectra of Mn 2p3/2, O 1 s and Fe 2p over the series Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts. From Fig. 5(a), the Mn 2p3/2 spectra for all the four catalysts exhibited two deconvoluted peaks located at 641.8 eV and 643.5 eV, ascribing to Mn3+ and Mn4+ species, respectively [40]. Based on the quantitative analysis of XPS spectrum, the pertinent content of various oxidized Mn species was counted. As seen in Table 2 , the relative contents of Mn4+ on the surface of Mn9Fe1, Mn8.5Fe1.5, Mn8Fe2 and Mn7.5Fe2.5 were 26.5%, 32.8%, 37.1% and 36.9%, respectively. The results revealed that the largest amount of Mn4+ species were exposed on the surface of Mn8Fe2, which was conducive to increasing the oxygen vacancy of the material and promoting the activation, adsorption and movement of oxygen species in the gaseous phase [41]. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the asymmetric O 1 s spectral deconvolution fractional peaks of these Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts were segmented into two, indicative of lattice oxygen (Olat) and surface adsorbed oxygen species (Oads) with the binding energy of about 529.5 eV and 531.0 eV, respectively [42]. Table 3 included the binding energy and relative surface content of different oxygen species in each sample, the relative percentage of Olat on the surfaces of Mn9Fe1, Mn8.5Fe1.5, Mn8Fe2 and Mn7.5Fe2.5 were 71.9%, 73.0%, 76.9%, and 73.1%, respectively. According to the MVK mechanism, lattice oxygen species on the catalyst surface were straightly participated in the combustion process of VOCs [43]. Therefore, for Mn8Fe2, the abundant Olat species on its surface was conducive to its excellent catalytic performance in the propane combustion reaction. The Fe 2p orbital spectrum of the various catalysts was presented in Fig. 5(c), the signal peaks intensities of Fe 2p on the catalyst surface gradually enhanced with the increase of Fe doping amounts. The Fe 2p1/2 peaks and Fe 2p3/2 peaks of the catalysts appeared at 723.9 eV and 710.6 eV, and an oscillating satellite peak appeared at 718.9 eV. The 2p orbital splitting energy of Fe was 13.3 eV, indicating that Fe was a high spin state [44]. All of these characteristics were attributed to the presence of Fe3+ in Fe2O3. As mentioned in XRD before, some Fe3+ ions had been doped into the lattice of MnO2, the Fe3+ presented in the XPS spectrum demonstrated that Fe doping played a significant role in phase transition. 3.6 H2-TPR H2-TPR experiment was used to investigate the reduction properties of Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts with different Fe/M molar ratios. The H2-TPR curves of all samples were displayed in Fig. 6 (a), which all contained multiple reduction peaks and were mainly distributed in the medium-low temperature region. The peaks of Mn9Fe1 and Mn8.5Fe1.5 at 250–380 °C were ascribed to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 and then to Mn3O4, as well as Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 [45,46]. At 405–450 °C, a peak was observed which corresponded to the reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO. On the other hand, the reduction peak observed between 700 and 720 °C was considered to be the reduction of FeO to Fe [44]. When the Fe/M molar ratio was increased from 1:10 to 1:5 in as-prepared catalysts, the reduction peaks of Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts negatively shifted. The initial reduction peaks of Mn8Fe2 corresponding to the lowest temperature, demonstrating that it had the best low temperature reducibility, resulting from the weakened Mn-O bond and the synergistic interaction between Mn and Fe caused by Fe doping [47,30]. However, the reduction peak of Mn7.5Fe2.5 migrated toward the higher temperature, indicating that excessive doping of Fe restrained the reduction capacity of the catalysts. It was concluded that the suitable content of Fe doping was more conducive to improving the low temperature reducibility of the catalysts. 3.7 O2-TPD O2-TPD tests were utilized to estimate the oxygen species on the surface of catalysts with different Fe/M molar ratios. As seen in Fig. 6(b), all the desorption peaks could be separated into three forms of oxygen species according to temperature range. The regions below 200 °C, between 450 and 700 °C, and above 700 °C, which should be assigned to the desorption of physical adsorbed oxygen (OI), subsurface lattice oxygen (OII), and bulk lattice oxygen (OIII), respectively. [48–50]. With the increase of Fe content, the desorption peaks intensities in the OI region increased gradually, indicating Fe doping could enlarge the specific surface area of the as-prepared samples, which might be the reason for the increase of OI desorption. Therefore, the adsorption and activation of oxygen molecules on the catalyst surface were promoted. With increasing the Fe doping, the desorption peaks intensities of oxygen in the OII region became stronger first and then weakened, and the peaks of catalysts shifted toward the lower temperature. Mn8Fe2 showed the strongest peak intensity and lower desorption temperature, demonstrating that Mn8Fe2 had abundant OII and great oxygen species mobility. It was worth noting that the high oxygen mobility of Mn8Fe2 could help it adsorbed more oxygen to participate in propane oxidation [51]. However, with increasing the mole ratio of Fe/M, the intensity of the desorption peak in the OIII region first decreased and then increased. It might be Fe doping reduced the crystallinity of MnO2 and strengthened the Jahn-Teller effect result in weakening the Mn-O bond, which was consistent with the H2-TPR analysis, thus promoting oxygen species to diffuse from the bulk phase to the surface [52]. 3.8 Raman spectrum Raman spectrum was measured to perform the Fe doping influence on surface chemical bond properties. Fig. 7 displayed three major peaks at around 184, 572 and 630 cm−1 in all catalysts, which were owing to the frame vibration of MnO2, the Mn-O stretching vibration in the basal plane of [MnO6] and the symmetric vibration of Mn-O bonds in [MnO6] groups, respectively [53,54]. According to the Hooke's law, the Mn-O bond force constant was calculated utilizing the approximately 630 cm−1 Raman shift [55]. Mn8Fe2 exhibited the minimum force constant, implying the stretching vibration between the Mn-O bond was weaker. As a consequence, the Mn-O chemical bonds became weaker, making them more susceptible to fracture for oxygen vacancy defects formation [56,57]. 3.9 Catalytic performance Propane conversions over the Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts was shown in Fig. 8 . Table 4 listed the main propane conversions indices. We compared the catalytic activity of Mn8Fe2 on propane with that of MnO2 presented in the literature, as shown in Table 5 . By comparison, it was found that the Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts we synthesized had advantages in catalytic combustion of propane. It could be seen from Fig. 8 that MnO2 catalysts with various Fe content promoted propane combustion to different levels. It evidenced from Table 4, Mn9Fe1 was the least active, the T90 required for propane combustion was 337 °C. However, Mn8Fe2 exhibited optimal catalytic activity on propane combustion, with T90 reaching 279 °C, which was approximately 58 °C inferior to that over the Mn9Fe1. This was primarily on account of the larger specific surface area, more loose pores, and the best low temperature reducibility of Mn8Fe2. In view of the above XRD test results, the low crystallinity of Mn8Fe2 implied that the presence of more defects in its structure, it was further revealed that the introduction of Fe changed the crystal phase of MnO2, which was conducive to the adsorption and activation of gas molecules and provided more reactive sites. In conclusion, an appropriate amount of Fe doping in MnO2 was more beneficial to prepare the catalysts with better catalytic performance. Fig. 9 displayed the Arrhenius plots of Mn9Fe1, Mn8.5Fe1.5, Mn8Fe2 and Mn7.5Fe2.5, the corresponding apparent activation energies could be gained by utilizing the Coats-Redfern method, as shown in Fig. 10 . By comparing these Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts, Mn8Fe2 exhibited the lowest activation energy, which promoted the catalytic reaction. Besides, the porous structure of Mn8Fe2 was more conducive to the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules. Its surface oxygen species were more likely to be activated and participated in the reaction at low temperature, which was consistent with the propane conversions of the catalysts. Space velocity was identified as a significant element affecting the catalytic combustion of VOCs. Mn8Fe2 was utilized to investigate the effect of different space velocities on the propane conversion. As seen from Fig. 11 and Table 6 , it exhibited optimal catalytic activity on propane combustion at a space velocity of 30,000 mL/(g·h), with T90 reaching 279 °C. Nevertheless, as the WHSV was rose to 60,000 mL/(g·h), the T90 value increased to 310 °C. The results demonstrated that the catalysts reduced the removal efficiency of propane at high space velocities, which might be on account of the reduced duration of exposure between the propane molecules and the catalysts, and the underreacting propane molecules were carried out of the reactor, resulting in a lower propane conversion. In the process of VOCs catalytic combustion, the stability of a catalyst was also a significant factor in measuring its performance. The stability of Mn8Fe2 was tested at 310 °C and WHSV of 60,000 mL/(g·h). As was presented in the Fig. 12 (a), during the continuous 12 h catalytic reaction, the conversion of Mn8Fe2 to remove propane remained almost 90%. Therefore, we concluded that Mn8Fe2 had excellent stability and promising application prospects. Presence of water vapor unavoidably affected the catalytic performance of the catalysts in the industrial application. The water resistance of Mn8Fe2 was test at 310 °C and WHSV of 30,000 mL/(g·h). 6% water vapor was brought into the reaction of Mn8Fe2 to explore the influence of water vapor on the catalytic combustion of propane. As seen from Fig. 12(b), Mn8Fe2 was presented the best catalytic activity of when the amount of water vapor introduced in the primary stage was zero, the conversion of propane attained 100%. Following a duration of 2.5 h, water vapor caused the conversion of propane decreased from 100% to 91.3%. It indicated that the water vapor restricted the catalytic performance of the catalysts, which was ascribed to the adsorption of water vapor as it competed with propane and oxygen molecules for active sites. After 10 h of continuous reaction, cut off the water vapor and propane conversion gradually increased until it returned to the initial degree. This showed that the catalytic activity of Mn8Fe2 was reversibly influenced by the water vapor, demonstrating it had a great water resistance. 3.10 Reaction mechanism In order to explore the catalytic mechanism underlying propane oxidation on Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts, the temperature-dependent in situ DRIFTs were determined and presented in Fig. 13 . The bonds observed at 1393 and 2969 cm−1 were ascribed to asymmetric vibration of δs(CH3) and υas(CH2), which were assigned to the gaseous propane absorption [63]. The peak detected at 1660 cm−1 was attributed to the asymmetric vibration of δas(HOH), implying the hydroxyl group was a group in the intermediate products in the propane oxidation process [24,61]. Furthermore, the bonds located at 1445, 1583 and 1727 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibration of υs(COO) and υs(C = O), indicating the intermediats were the carbonate and carboxylate species [61,64,65]. And some peaks at 1056, 1204 and 1328 cm−1 were assigned to the asymmetric vibration υas(CO-C), the symmetric υs(CO-C) and asymmetric vibration υas(CO) of bonds of ester group [65–67]. According to the MVK mechanism, propane molecules were oxidized by Olat of Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts, generating oxygen vacancies and reducing Mn4+ to Mn3+. Simultaneously, Oads was activated by oxygen vacancies to supplement Olat and reoxidized Mn3+ to Mn4+. Since the Oads were electrophilic, it could capture H atoms from adsorbed propane to generate alkyl radicals or combine with C atoms to generate ester groups and carbonyl [24]. Based on the above discussions, we reasonably proposed the mechanism of the as-prepared samples for propane combustion, which was shown in Scheme 2 . Firstly, propane molecules were adsorbed on the surface of the Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts. After adsorbing, propane was activated and reacted with the reactive oxygen species, which was converted into carbonate and carboxylate intermediates. The intermediate products were finally converted into CO2 and H2O by reactive oxygen species. The substitution of Fe for some Mn in the MnO2 could induce a portion of the Mn3+ to oxidize to Mn4+ and benefit the formation of lattice defects and oxygen vacancies to balance the general charge. At the same time, Fe doping caused the exposure of additional interior atoms and facilitated the generation of mesoporous structures in MnO2, thus increasing specific surface area and providing a greater number of active sites for catalyzing oxidation reaction. Furthermore, during the process of Fe doping, the synergistic interaction between Mn and Fe enhanced and the Mn-O bond weakened even fractured, which caused abundant Mn4+and Olat species on its surface to be generated. The generation of Mn4+/Mn3+ redox couple accelerated the active oxygen species, which was conductive to improve the catalytic performance. The abundant Olat species on its surface was conducive to its excellent catalytic performance in the propane combustion reaction. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we successfully prepared different Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts. Physicochemical characterization results showed that increasing the Fe/Mn molar ratios, the crystalline phase of MnO2 gradually changed from α-MnO2 and β-MnO2 to Fe2O3, the particle size of catalysts decreased and the specific surface area increased. The introduction of Fe provided more oxygen vacancies and active sites for the reaction, which was conducive to enhance the catalytic performance of MnO2 catalysts. Among them, the largest amount of Mn4+ species and lattice oxygen species were exposed on the surface of Mn8Fe2, and showed the best low temperature reducibility, which was ascribed to the synergistic effect between Mn and Fe was enhanced, resulting in its catalytic activity of propane having the most positive effect. The best catalytic performance of Mn8Fe2 was presented with a T90 of 279 °C. Besides, Mn8Fe2 exhibited superb stability and water tolerance in propane combustion. This work given a simple perspective into the influence regularity of Fe content in MnO2 on the catalytic combustion of propane, and presented a new way to design and synthesize non-noble metal catalysts for the elimination of propane. coredata.dc:description: Manganese oxides were received extensive attention on account of its low cost, variable valence state and excellent redox properties. Herein, we successfully prepared various Fe-doped MnO2 catalysts to further improve the catalytic activity of MnO2 on propane. Physicochemical characterization results displayed that with the increase of Fe doping amounts, the crystalline phase of MnO2 gradually changed from α-MnO2 and β-MnO2 to Fe2O3, the particle size of catalysts decreased and the specific surface area increased. However, increasing the content of Fe could not monotonically enhance the catalytic performance of catalysts on propane. When the molar ratio of Fe/Mn was 0.25, the largest amount of Mn4+ species and lattice oxygen species were exposed on the surface of Mn8Fe2, and showed the best low temperature reducibility, which was ascribed to the synergistic effect between Mn and Fe was enhanced. It presented optimal catalytic activity for propane oxidation with temperature of propane conversion at 90% (T90) as low as 279 °C under 0.1% propane and 5% O2. This work provided a new way to design and synthesize efficient non-noble metal catalysts for the elimination of propane, which had certain application value.
coredata.dc:title: Fe-doped MnO2 as an efficient catalyst for low temperature propane oxidation
